rtega_mnemonic:
穗穗RS
穂穂		ear of grain, tassel, fruits or grains in a cluster grown at the tip of a stem or stalk
  • favour 惠/恵 given by grain stalks 禾
heisig_keyword: ear of a plant | початок растения
heisig_constituent: ear (of a plant), wheat, cereal, favour, favor, ten, needle, rice field, brains, heart
koohiiStory1: The pilgrims only had wheat, so they asked the Indians to do them a favor and trade them for some ears of corn.
koohiiStory2: The "ear of a plant" is the seed-bearing spike of a cereal plant, such as corn. In other words, it is the part which feeds us. Hence -- "the ear (of a plant) is the favor of the wheat".
jp_example_words: 穂(ほ): ear (of plant), head (of plant)
WaniKani_Kanji_Meaning: Head of Plant, Ear Of Plant
WaniKani_Meaning_Mnemonic: The part of the grain people favor the most is the head of the plant. You don't eat the stems and leaves of rice or wheat plants, right? You eat the head where the grains are.
WaniKani_Meaning_Info: Imagine yourself walking through a field of rice plants. Now look very closely at the head of the plant in front of you. See the rice bunched up there? That's the good stuff.
WaniKani_Reading_Mnemonic: When you want to harvest the head of the plant you'd like to eat, you need to use a hoe (ほ). Using a hoe, you can dig up the bottom of the plant without injuring the head.
WaniKani_Reading_Info: Imagine working in a field of rice and using a hoe so you don't injure the head of the plant. You're sweating and it's hot, but you keep at it.
Ru_Radicals: 十 (десять), 心 (сердце), 田 (рисовое поле), 禾 (ость колоса)
Kanshudo_mnemonic: the grain (禾) you're blessed with (恵) has ears

Name meaning

suì
яп. вм. 穗
Radicals: 禾, 恵  (grain, favor)
Meaning Mnemonic
The part of the grain people favor the most is the head of the plant. You don't eat the stems and leaves of rice or wheat plants, right? You eat the head where the grains are.
Imagine yourself walking through a field of rice plants. Now look very closely at the head of the plant in front of you. See the rice bunched up there? That's the good stuff.
Reading Mnemonic
When you want to harvest the head of the plant you'd like to eat, you need to use a hoe (ほ). Using a hoe, you can dig up the bottom of the plant without injuring the head.
Imagine working in a field of rice and using a hoe so you don't injure the head of the plant. You're sweating and it's hot, but you keep at it.
